text: Rating from the backlog - bottle drunk on-site in November 2016. Woody sourish parts, very round with funky parts, vinegar, deep and still round. Interesting great stuff.
Draft - Pours golden amber, no head / low carb. Aroma is wood, white grape, floral notes, lemon, oak. Flavor is funky oak/lemon/must, fairly acidic.

Bottle 375ml. @ Cantillon Brewery/Museum, 56 rue Gheude, Brussels, Belgium 1070. [ As Cantillon Iris Grand Cru ].Clear medium orange amber color with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light caramel, sweet malt - sugary, wood, oak, citric, soft funk. Flavor is moderate sweet and light acidic with a long duration, wood, oxidide, sweet malt, dry, soft funk. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. [20160916]
 7-2-8-3-16

Pours murky rose hip with minimal head 
Aromas tart of earth, leaves, garden branch
Taste has funky notes of earth, over ripe fruits, mold leaves, garden branch,

75cl bottle at the brewery. It pours a clean rich golden orange color with a minimal bubbly white head. Aroma is tart and astringently acidic, with notes of lemon juice, dried leaves, grass, funky basement. Taste is also acidic and lemony, with more big funk notes. This is quite grassy and lightly metallic. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, interesting but not my cup of tea

Bottle at the brewery, clear deep oxidsed orange color, aroma of vanila, aged vinegar, dried apricots, white raisons and a hint of barnyard, amazing aroma, extremely mellow, flavor of vanila, spices and sour bread. Tasty, great to linger on and probably excellent with a meal.

From notes. This was enjoyed at Jolly Pumpkin on October 1 for Zwanze Day 2016! The pour is surprisingly almost not carbonated. Its a ruby-tinted orange without any head. The aroma is really funky and acidic. There is a wet wood and a funkiness happening thats pretty strong. There is a sharpness to it and a lightly metallic bit on the back end. The flavor is much of the same. Its harsh, acidic, funky, and carries a light metallic fruit to it. The mouth feel is thick and syrupy with a metallic flavor lingering on the palate. Im not a fan of this one that much.
Bottle at Cantillon. Pours clear copper. Aroma tart sour, vinegar, some funk, citrus. Taste tart sour, vinegar. Very dry and bitter.

Draft at Thin Mans 2016 Zwanze Day. Pours a dark, slightly hazy copper color with a small tan sudsy head. Aromas of funk, wood, wet hay and grass, dill. Flavor follows the nose with bits of lemon mixed in. Solid, but my least favorite of the day. Light body and texture, medium carb, dry and sour finish.
Bottle @ Cantillon. Pours clear copper with no head. Aroma of barn, acid acetic, light barn, quite sweet, flowery. Taste is rather sour with loads of sweetness, and a dry woody touch.

Draft->tumbler at Sovereign (opening day, and again on Zwanze Day). Dark copper-orange with no head. Funky wood and tart citrus, wet hay. Lacks some of the sharpness I like, leaving it a bit, well, greasy. Still very good.

Draught. Pours a cloudy amber-orange with a negligible white head. Aroma is wood, grass, lactic, and funk. Taste is similar but with the addition of acetic acid, light berries, honey, and some malt. Dry. Medium body. No carbonation. Mouthfeel is a little thin.
Grapefruit and some cracker and pepper. Guava and passionfruit. Hazy brown pour without any head or lacing. Tangy finish. Big thanks to Matt for this. Sovereign.

Draught at Akkurat Zwanse 2016.
Slight hazy deep copper orange, no gead.
Nose: acidic with picklejuice, barrel, wood, funk, cornichons.
Taste: soft acidic with cornichons and slight grapefruit/lemon, wood and grass.
Medium body, no carb almost, oily.
Like the normal one better actually.

On tap at JK Zwanze... Pours totally still... Slight tan orange in color... Aroma of overripe fruits, funk, acetic notes... Flavor is kinda thin, light acetic, funk, hay, overripe fruits... Delicious 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Zwanze 2016. Nose is very tart smelling. Acidic. Hazy orange with minimal white head. Light citrus as it warms. Orange notes. Taste is moderately sour, nearly still. Lightly acetic, not bad but not that great either.

Tap into a wineglass showing lightly filtered tea orange brown with no head. 

The nose shows a lot of tart brett notes with very subtle oak and apricot. 

The palate is medium bodied and not carbonated. Flavors of light oak with an extremely gentle tartness. Not much else, short and simple.

Bottle shared at Cantillon. Clear golden brown with a few off white bubbles. Aroma of oak, toffee, light citric notes, a touch lactic and a soft funk. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and moderate sour. Medium bodied with near flat carbonation. [17-09-2016]

On tap at Redlight Redlight. Originally reviewed 9/15/2013.

Flat deep reddish brown. Lifeless and a little hazy.

Nose is very oaky. A little vinegary. Malty with a complex acidic aroma. Lactic, acetic, everything going on. Sweetness, sourness, oak, caramel.

Tastes of a variety of malt flavors. Caramel and toast. Sourness kicks in. Lemony at first, but vinegar behind it. Oak rounds it out nicely. Complex.

Well its flat. Bit it doesnt bother me much. The flavors come out more due to the lack of carbonation, so its a trade off.

Stunned that this could be as good as it was. The absence of hops really lets the malt complexity shine through. Reminds me of a well-put-together BFM beer.
05-05-16 // sample at Cantillon Quintessence 2015. Wood and oak notes, some caramel, some citrus notes. Much more complex than the regular Iris. But I prefer the regular one.

A 375ml bottle at the brewery, brewed on 5th March 2013, bottled on 26th May 2016 and poured into a Cantillon tasting glass. It poured a clear copper orange colour with pretty much no head and sparse lacing. Aromas were funky, sour, grapefruit, lemon, leather and oak. Tastes funky, barnyard, sour, caramel, bitter melon bitterness, grapefruit, lemon and oak. Light to medium bodied with no carbonation. Overall this was nice and easy to drink and I preferred it over the Bruocsella Grand Cru. Ive yet to try Iris though, so cant compare it to that yet.

Warm golden colour, white head. Aroma of wood, cigars, ceder, brett, light lemon, earth and somewhat floral. Light sour flavour, citric, ceder, wood, light citrus. Quite astringent. Loads of wood notes in the finish.(from 75cL bottle @ Cantillon Quintessence 2016)
Sample @ Cantillon Quintessence 2016. Fruity with brett, also acidic. The finish is dry.

Bottle at Cantillon - shared with Mette. Clear golden/amber - offwhite bubbles. 
Wooden. Flowery. Light fat notes. Tannins. Ok sour. Light grape fruity. Tart. Light perfumed notes. Lovely.

bittle @ Cantillon. Light copper pour with hardly any head. Nose is interesting. Tea, earth, mild caramel. Flavor is musty cheesy. Lemon. Flowers and leaves. Interesting dry hopping. Cork. Light body, basically still. Decent.

01/07/2016 - 37,5cl bottle @ Brewery.
Clear amber, no head, flat. Nose is wood sugar, burnt notes. Taste has burn notes, hints of sherry, lemon. Oily mouthfeel. Dry ending. More refined than regular.

Draught. Light hazy deep amber liquid with small white head. Aroma of lemon, apple skin, raw sugar, floral hops and wood. Taste is very light sweet and light to medium sour with notes of lemon, apple skin, mineral and light grain. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Great stuff. Quite a lot like an Oude Lambiek. Not a lot of dry hop left. Still, nice.

Bottle at Cantillon. Pours clear dark orange with a small amount of white bubbles. Aroma is lightly caramelized malt, lactic sourness, lemon notes and light earthy and stale hops. Flavor is lightly caramelized malt, lactic sourness, light earthy hops, faint bitterness, black walnuts, oak and light cellar notes with a dry finish. Light body and faint carbonation.
Sample @ Cantillon Quintessence 2016. Fruity, bretty and woody, acidic, medium body, the finish is dry.

Pours a flat, slightly hazed golden yellow color.

Smells of funky cream cheese, mold, old cork and wet hay. Leather adds to sun dried earth and old oak, while a flowery lemon inclusion is responsible for a prominent tartness.

Almost no carbonation in this, which leads to a sour smack on the tongue, refreshing and soft in the finish, while challenging sour and dry until the swallow. 

Flowers, grass, dusty old wood and lots of blue cheese establish the foundation in this. Lemon zest hits the palate in an uncompromising, almost harsh fashion, numbing the teeth from the outside. Its flowery quality cuts through this dominant tartness during the finish, establishing a late softness on the tongue.

Big, as for its sour-dry blend, which is a bit too powerful for my palate, making it hard to pick up anything else. Has a nice finish though, with a great aqueous softness to it, soothing the lime.
Sample at Quintessense 2016. Light orange, uncarbonated. Aroma is dried fruits, plum, sherry. Light-medium bodied, lightly sticky mouthfeel, dried stone fruits, oak, prune.
Sample @ Cantillon Quintenssence. Dark orange body with no head. Wood, yeast and brett, sligltly sweet, dusty . Dry finish. Low carbonation. Glad to have tried this.
UPDATED: MAY 7, 2016 Beer tasting @ cantillon brussels. Pours a dark orange colour beer with a small head. Fruity, yeasty and bretty with some sweetness and wood. Dry finish
Clear deep golden/Amber color. Moderate head with mild tartness and some sweetness. This is an extremely drinkable beer.

Draft at Quintessence 2016. Side by side with the regular Iris. This one doesnt have the bitterness, but has a full flavour of the wooden barrel, citrus-like, perfectly in balance and low carbonation. Lovely.
Vollmundig säuerlicher Antrunk, Noten von Getreide, trocken. Die komplexe Säure bleibt auf angenehmem Level, minimal bitter. Langer runder Nachhall, spritzig, Heunoten. 10/11/11/11//11

Quintessence 2016. Light hazy light amber, almost no head. Grains, wet grain, hay, corn, little watery, poppy seeds, less hoppiness than the original. Very light sour, light salty. Minerallike, under medium body. Pairing with Rochefort cheese is amazing but standalone its a bit disappointing.

From keg at Cantillon during Quintessence. Clear orange golden with no head. Wood, twigs, soft ash, dust, funk, sour grains, dried flowers and herbs. Quite dry, bitter and ashy with some sourness and a hint of sweetness running through. Over medium bodied with no carbonation.
Keg at La Capsule, Lille, France. Amber with white head. There is a pleasant sourness from the start of this, good woody hints, some fruitiness. Palate cleansing citrus hits. A really pleasant beer.

On tap @ IBF Pub Edition, Milano. Intensità olfattiva è elevata e la persistenza olfattiva è considerevole. Il colore è ambrato carico. Il corpo è strutturato pesante. Lamaro è medio. Lintensità gustativa è elevata e la persistenza gustativa è buona. Il gusto è estremo. Il finale è complesso.
Nice funky aroma with earthy spiciness, clear barnyard and a bit nuttiness. Citrus, and lemon all through, extremely drinkable, and prefer this to GCB.

From tap at Akkurat. Almost clear red amber color with off white head. Yeasty and malty aroma, barnyard, fruity, wood, wineous, caramel. Sweet and acidic taste like aroma. Light to medium, thin to oily body with soft carbonation.

Spina @ eurhop 2015.
Ambrata senza schiuma.
Secca astringente acida, molto amara.
Prima cantillon che non mi fa impazzire  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Mi4i

(Cantillon Iris Grand Cru) Tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas during Zwanze Day. 250 ml glass. 
Deep red colour, mostly clear, with a small frothy head on top. Low retention.
Aromas of funk, basement, cheese, wheat, mold.
On the taste light caramel, mold, basement, nice fruity notes surfacing after a while, after it has breathed a bit.
Medium thin body, low carbonation.
Good.

Glass on tap at Parker Pie. Aroma: ripped apples, wild cherries. App: hazy brown with yellow tint, kinda murky, no head. Taste and palate: thin body, watery, no carbonation, sour, oaky and fruity finish. Overall: was expecting much more. What a deception. No carbonation at all combined with the fact that it?s watery makes this beer not really that good, really up to Cantillon standards.

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels, Belgium. CLear amber, low head. Vinous, spicy aniseed and fenugreek aroma, some notes of wood. Medium bodied, low to medium carbonation. Dry, medium acidity.

On tap at Blue Monk in Buffalo, NY for Zwanze Day. Light reddish pour. Never had the other Iris so not sure how to compare. Really not very sour, kinda sweet, a little bit of almost a cognac feel. Solid.

Draft:
Hazy, orange/amber with a small, off-white head.
Neutral yeast, slightly woody aroma.
Taste is fairly bitter over the tartness...tannic, woody.
Ok, but not exactly appealing for much more than a sample.

(2013, on tap @ Akkurat for Zwanze Day, Sept 19 2015) Pours clear dark amber with basically no head, just a few ephemeral white bubbles. Aroma is sharply acidic, astringent and woody, old lambic with musty attic funk. There is fruitiness underneath though, red berries and maybe stone fruit or citrus. Sweaty socks too, as it warms. Palate is bright lactic and maybe a bit acetic, over a bit of sweetish malt with a tart berry hint, gooseberry maybe? Finish is dry and a bit acidic with lots of wood, attic, a touch medicinal from old hops. Astringent in the aftertaste. Fairly light bodied with almost no carbonation. Not the most accessible Cantillon, its a little brusque and thin and unbalanced though air seemed to help it. Its interesting, with its buried fruitiness and wood contrast but I wouldnt drink tons of it - it doesnt ask for it.

Special, limited edition of Cantillons Iris, shared with 77ships, sebletitje and Craftmember at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Practically no head, just a minute rim of off-white, loose, tiny bubbles vanishing quickly, colour misty amber with a brownish hue. Pleasant aroma of oloroso sherry, overripe gooseberry, redcurrant, yoghurt, wet wood, leather, wet hay, soaked bread. Very estery onset, overripe berries and stonefruit with a honeyish edge, after which a drying tartness sets in, quite mals and lactic, with low lemony acidity; full lambic funkiness, very sherryish, drying with a light, deeply buried old hops bitterishness in the end, quenching and tart. Very interesting: its been at least seven years since I last had the regular Iris, but I cannot remember it being like this, the alterations have apparently resulted in a very different lambic altogether.
Draft. Pours dark orange - Nose/taste of light caramel, lemon, oak and funk - medium body.
Tap at Scheras for Zwanze day. Hazy dark golden pour. Aroma is funk and cheese. Taste is really mild, kind of thin but not bad. Unblended style is tough.
On tap at Holy Grale. Orange with very small off-white head. Aroma is tart, light body, low carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is tart, oak, and earthy.
Tap at Scheras. Slightly murky light orange / gold pour with a white head. Funky, cheese, hay. Dry finish. Quite good.

Draft at akkurakt.
Red amber no head clear.
Aroma of cherry cellar, honey.
Taste sour cherry, dry tart, some sweetness. 
Hints of bitterness. 
Lovley!!

Draft at akkurat
Wonderful sourness, amber, grapes in aroma. Extremmly balanced, wonderful finish. Great palate, wow

Poured from tap at Novare Res pours amber brown with a thin head. Aromas of fruit oak wine and hints of floral biscuit. Taste is tart with notes of sour funk mild fruit and a lingering bitterness. Not very balanced.
Draft. Brown pour with white head. Floral, fruity, oak, wine aromas. Floral, fruit, light malt sour tones. Would love to see how this ages.

draft, poured a slight hazy light amber colour with some fuzzy bubbles on top. nose has old malts, funk, old dusty cellar, white grapes, oak, and a note of lemons, slight tart with a herbal-ish finish. i prefer the regular iris above this one.

Draught @ Akkurat. Pours tiny hazy deep golden with a small head that doesnt leave much trace on the glass when dissipating. Smell is slightly fruity and heavy funky with sourdough crackers, blue cheese, lemon juice, hay, dry soil, minerals, leather, horse blanket, barnyard, orange zest and and lemon zest. Taste is sour, bitter, tiny fruity and heavy funky. Mouthfeel is dry, tart, tiny astringent and medium bodied. Finish is sour and slightly bitter with sourdough crackers, mouldy old bread, blue cheese, lemon juice, hay, dry soil, leather, barnyard and lemon zest. Heavy funky and slightly weird. Cool but a bit hard to drink.

Draft to 5 oz stemmed glass at Zwanze Day today. Looks solid; a slightly translucent orangish brown with bubbly eggshell lacing. Smells semi-tart and floral with a bit of biscuit. Tastes like it smells, but less balanced, with a medium-light to medium-bodied mouthfeel. Pretty bitter. Not bad, but unbalanced and underwhelming.

Cask @ ML Fontainas Zwanze Wknd 2015.
Couleur ambrée, qcq bulles beige.
Arôme met en avant un boisé chêne et des effluves un peu plus dominante de caramel. Retrouve un rétro fruité rappelant une pomme caramel et un petit coin de fleuri assez frais, houblonné vert.
Palais garde un profil axé sur le boisé, et un savant mélange de lambics qui offrent un profil cuire, léger funk avec une pointe presque oxydée. Fleuri rappelant une sorte de thé froid, voire de cidre. Effervescence moyenne - faible pour un fini suret modéré. Le tout conserve un côté finement terreux.
Draft: Poured a caramel color with no head. The nose was a sour pungent mix. Taste was funky floral with light sour, some nice woodsiness too.

Cask pour at the source. The beer is a still copper color with no head or sign of carbonation. The beer smells musty and woody. Some mild bitterness peaks through, but the beer is mostly sweet and woody. Touches of sour start to come out as i drink the beer, but it just never quite gets there.

Welcoming Wood cask [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ hall opening 05/2015, merci. Meaty, ponderous deep amber pour, with an unusual beige glare. Very heavy oak barrel and pure potent barley in the nose, oozing from under that suave horseblanket...as there is no wheat here, it is technically not even a lambic, dixit Van Roy. Still it is ample savoury-sweet and mildly sour like an old lambic, while the trademark Cantillon preserved lemon and even grapefruit zest has been layered over by an almost savoury-bitter broth of wood notes, sherry, decaramelised doppelbock barleys, old demure apple cider. A layered, headstrong flat adult lemonade for the unsqueamish and unchildish.
Poured at Cantillon - pours Amber. Hoppy bitter in the nose plus lemon zest. Taste is bitter, some cherry, sweet.

Poured from the cask by Jean at the opening of the new facility. Clear light amber pour with a white head. Mild sour aromas. Sour with hoppy bitterness and floral highlights. No carbonation as it was from the cask. Bitter and sour with funk, barnyard, and caramel malt notes. Good body and mouthfeel.

At the opendoorday of the new barrelroom. Thnx jean! Pours rather clear bit amber. Smell is rather malty, bit wild yeasts. Taste is very elegant. Very complex and fine, but with a serious backbone of maltyness. Bit buttery - ina good way. Nice mouthfeel!

Draught. Pours hazy amber with a small whitish head. Damp cellar, funky notes, some faint earthyness and old stable notes in aroma. Tart fruity and white wine grapes at first in taste, some apples and sour notes too. Later on some wooden notes mixed with little bit of lemon appears as well. Oak, even some bitters and vinegary notes aftertaste.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 20 Sep 2014) Brownish amber colour with brief head. Fruity, sourish nose with notes of caramel, stable, grass and burnt sugar. Fruity, tart taste with caramel, stable, cellar, bitter almonds and a fresh sourness in the finish. Medium body, quite dry. A bit different from the regular Iris, but still a nice one.

[5853-20130928] Tap. Sour fruity yeast aroma. Slightly hazy, red body with no lasting head. Sour fruity yeast flavour. Medium body is wonderfully sour and even a little peppery. Delicious. (8/3/9/4/17) 4.1
(Anniversary Party @ Volo, Toronto, ON)

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Amber hazy reddish. Wood, sours and funk. Overripe sour red apples, well blended oak in flavour. Med bodied, softly tart. Sour berries, barnyard. Quite fruity actually, oaky fruity. As a beer, great, but not the best cantillon.-- bb
Tap at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Colour is deep brownish red with very small white head. Aromas and flavors: Berries, wood, some sweetness and sourness. Fresh and woody.

(Keg at Pikkulintu, 20141129) The beer poured almost mahogany coloured and quite clear. Its head was almost non-existent. Aroma had wood, vanilla, tartness, vomit, grapefruit and sourness. Palate was medium bodied and dry with quite low carbonation. Flavours were wood, sourness, vanilla, tartness, grapefruit and low bitterness. Aftertaste was woody, tart and mildly bitter. A tasty and surprisingly woody lambic.
On tap at churchkey. Dark copper color. A bit of lemon and some oak. A bit undercarbonated. sour component is a bit toned down for cantillon. Great stuff!

4oz pour at Churchkey pours a clear copper amber with some soapy white head. Nose has a ton of grapefruit, both juice and rind, wood pulp, soapy, very medicinal, vegetal too. Flavor has loads of grapefruit, some buttery oak notes, some band aid, medicine cabinet, grass, straw. Full, tart finish.

Served on-tap at Monks during Zwanze Day 2014


A - Pours murky brown with a very small white head, quickly dissipating down to nothing at all, leaving no lace what so ever on the glass.


S - Smells of typical Cantillon must, sweet grain, some light funk, oak and some light fruitiness. Not as bright of an aroma as I was expecting it to have but still nice.


T - Starts off with the sweet bready grains quickly being joined by a nice lemony lactic sour kick, barnyard funk, musty basement, woody oak, dash of grassy hop bitterness and some earthen minerals. Finish is quite dry, lingering long after the finish.


M - Medium body with moderate carbonation. Slick, flat feel from start to finish. The dryness is pretty tiring on the palate, doubt I could drink a whole bottle of this.


O - An interesting experimental lambic to say the least. I would love to have this again once it has some years to develop, I think it could really improve with some time on it. As it is a nice thing to try but with so many other great Cantillon beers out there I doubt I would revisit it anytime soon, if given the chance.
Copper-amber body, medium sized off white head, streaky lacing. Wood, deep must, funk, light grainy toffee. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, assertive acidity, slightly muddled finish.

Draught for Zwanze Day 2014. Pours a hazy reddish brown with little to no head or lacing. Aroma is lactic sourness, fruity sweetness, and a nice funky straw finish. Taste follows, lots of nice balance, sweet up front, malty middle, sour ending. Very nice, dry and refreshing finish.

Draught at Akkurat during Zwanze day.
Very light aroma of tart beer.
Spicy and herbal, smooth mouthfeel with a green hop bitterness.

@ Akkurat 14-9-20: fantastisk syrlig doft och smak med tydeliga vindruvor och hemlig beska. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
---- Soberness not garanteed!

Have had the regular Iris several times before in both bottles and on draft. Now managing to get the very last bit of a keg (a half tulip) of the Grand Cru at a sour event at Khyber Pass in Philly. Poured a hazy orange copper with no head. Tons of aged oak flavor. Still some nicy juiciness underneath. Quite sour and quite dry. Wonderfully complex!

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Tampere. Deep golden colour, no head. Aroma is sour wood, some quite sweet notes along with some meertse like notes as well. Flavour is tart wood, some slight sweetness along with mild wood as well as some mild resiny and sweet notes. Balanced, and somewhat different from the typical Cantillons.

On tap for Zwanze Day. Pour is dark copper amber with thin bubbly white ring. Nose has a strong oak presence, dusty and a hint of vanilla. Light cellar musk but faint. I hint of apricot in the back. Taste is heavily sour, virtually no carbonation on a tight creamy body. Lots of vanilla and oak, some notes of toffee and and caramel. Interesting beer, heavily sour with an interesting malt complexity. Faint earthy lambic notes but not much. More dusty wood and sour notes with an unusual malt presence that is enjoyable.
@ Quintessence. Even maltier and woodier than the first time I had it and compared to the regular Iris there is a lot going on. A great lambic with deep flavors of citrus, barnyard and malts.

Sampled on Zwanze Day 2013 at Alewife Queens, as well as at Denver Ghost Tasting (thanks to Sean!).. Massive oak bomb with an almost flat hop presence. Little lacing with a steady, if underdeveloped head, thin legs. Heavy funk, very minimal acidity. Sweet and malty, slight sourness with a mellow bitterness. A neat example of what can be done with extended oak aging, however not my favorite expression of Iris.

Draft @ Moeder over the weekend. Amber / gold, sticky head fades slowly. Nose is wild, raw, grape vines, peach skins clementine zest. Very dry taste, spice lemon tart not sour with a malty backbone. really interesting.

On tap @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Slightly hazy golden/orange with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of oak, funk, citric/lemony notes and caramel. Taste is also lemony with mild funk, mineral notes and caramel. Medium body. Flat carbonation. Dry finish. Like JulienHuxley said, this one is very similar to their unblended lambic (not the Bruoscella, the regular one). Its difficult to recognize regular Iris here. Quenching.

On tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Almost clear gold pour with a few bubbles of white head. Aroma of typical Cantillon funk, bretty, oaky notes, quite citric, a bit dusty. Taste is tart, lemony, Cantillon wet grain funkiness, very light caramel notes. This beer has nothing of what makes Iris Iris, stripped back down to old Cantillon lambic. It is however quite different from Grand Cru Bruoscella, and is quite quaffable. The age is more apparent in the aroma as well.

Tap @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Dark orange/amber colour, almost no carbonation. Complex sour aroma of sour apples, barnyard and citrus. Dry and light bitter finish. Funky and tart. Very good and drinkable.
Cask at Moeder. Pours orange brown with a off white cask froth. Aroma is oak, dark cherry, wet blanket, spice. Taste follows nose, sour cherry, oak and a touch of spice. Dry, cherry skin finish.
On tap at Akkurat. Hazy light red with no head. Aroma is tart cherries, hay, earthy and barnyard. Taste is tart fruity cherries, citrus, yeast. Smooth medium body, low carbonation. Refreshing.

On tap at Akkurat. 

Almost clear amber with a minimal head. The aroma was mild with citrus, funk and light earth. The taste was also quite mild, not that sour. Citrus, funk, some yeast and white wine. A relaxed and easy to drink Lambic. Its always a pleasure to drink a new one from Cantillon.

How: Draught.
Where: Akkurat, Stockholm.
Appearance: Amber colour with a minimal head.
Aroma: Sour, fruit, acidic.
Body: Medium body, very low carbonation.
Flavour: Citric, acidic, some yeast and funk.

Keg at Akkurat, Stockholm.  Hazy amber, minimal head. Funky cobwebs horseblanket up front. Surprisingly mild acidity, medium body, soft mouthfeel, low carbonation. Some citric acid, lots of horseblanket. Distinct stale hop bitterness. Relaxed, deep and seemless.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2014 Tap @ Tuulensuu
Clear amber coloured beer with no head. Aroma is sour with white wine and saddle leather, some sweetness and citrus crispness. Flavor is sour with white wine, apples and saddle leather. Finish is quite long, dry and sour but not bitter. Mouthfeel is flat and medium full. Not as sour as their gueuze, but because of the flat mouthfeel, not more easily drinkable. I dont get this stuff.
Tap at Tuulensuu. Pours dark orange with practically no head. Sour, earthy woody aroma, some grapes. Wood and berries, earth notes, smooth.

Draught at Moeder Lambic. It pours hazy amber-brown with a bubbly beige head. The nose is earthy, wet leaf, plenty of florals, hay, straw, must and wood. The taste is tart, earthy, acidic, big floral notes, wet wood, light bitterness and must with a dry, somewhat acidic finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Perhaps a touch acidic for my liking, but rather nice anyhow...

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere

Pours dark reddish orange with a bubbly head. Aroma of tart berries, sourness, earthy and floral notes. Taste is smooth, tartish and sourish with some notes of berries and earthiness. Finish is sour, sweetish and tart with notes of berries. Okay, quite raw and smooth lambic.

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu
Sour and earthy aroma with grapefruit. Flavour is rather sour with malty notes typical to Iris. Also floral notes, grapefruit and distant woody tones. Flat palate, no CO2 at all. I like the sourness here. Perhaps a bit more woody and less malty, but no big differences with the basic version.

Draft at ChurchKey poured into a tasting snifter. Surprised to see it still on for Thursday since it was tapped on Sunday, guess the whale hunters are on spring break. Pours a dark amber/golden brown with hardly any head. Aromas of vinegar, red wine, white wine, tart fruit. Tasting notes of vinegar, red wine, tart fruit, light oak. Medium-light body with a dry and tart vinegary finish. Thin mouthfeel, low carbonation. Pretty nice, hope to try the regular Iris some day.

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere. Pours a red colour with a minimal head. Aroma of sweet, coughdrops and wood. Flavour of wood, red berries, apricot, mint, caramel sweetness and coughdrops. Medium bodied, very dry mouthfeel and a dry, harsh, sweet finish. Low carbonation. Heavy. Some similarities with their Faro.

Tap @ Gastropub Tuulensuu.
Pours clear amber color with no head. Aroma of yeast, grapes, gooseberry bush and some wooden notes. Flavor of gooseberries, yeast, wood and apricot. Sour wooden dry palate. Very nice.

3365

On tap at the Cove. Pours a clear amber with small frothy whitr head. The aroma is strong funk, pepper, bandaids. Thin mouthfeel with strong funk, light pepper and sour with nice light dry finish. Very impressive.
Tap (at Holy Grale). Musty yeast, lemon, and light malt aroma. Golden yellow with minimal head. Musty, dry sour lemon juice, light malt, and yeast flavor. Lightly bitter aftertaste. Delicate.

Sample from growler. 

The amber lambic got a aroma of candid apples. Somewhat the aroma of a barley wine. The oak is forward, and pushes me to think of a bourbon. Harsh sourness in the back of the mouth, thats not so nice, but smother on the front of the tongue.
Orange small head acidity tart woody wild fruit medium acidity very dry medium low bitterness
Tart fruit on the nose. Pours a light amber with no carbonation. Tart and acidic upfront hints of cranberry and finishes very tart and dry.

From tap at moeder lambic fontainas. Pours hazy amber with little white and long lasting head. Aroma is tart, sour apples, touch of vinegar. Taste is tart, apples, very sour. Light bitter aftertaste. Good balanced between sour, bitter and fruity.

Had this at the Churchkey in DC. Poured into a jelly glass. The restaurant was dark so I couldnt make out the color, but there was no head or carbonation. It was also served a little warmer than I expected, which relaxed what could have been an overpoweringly sour experience. Really, my tastebuds shriveled at the incredibly sour aroma.

This is a sour beer, but it was definitely meaty and earthy as well. Ive had too many BB sours lately, so I appreciate the oak barrels used here.

This was a pleasant, though kind of simple oak-sour. Ill definitely drink again, though I wouldnt pay $13 for a glass of this again.

Draft at ChurchKey for Night of the Living Ales: Part 3. Poured a slightly hazy, red-brown color with a murky hue to it along with a white head. Aroma was sour notes, woody character. Some sweet notes, a touch of funk. Pretty good.
Draft. Cloudy amber brown, almost flat. Aroma of sour stone fruit, light feet. Taste is tart prach, light vanilla, white wine. Nice.
Du beurre, du cuir, une touche de vinaigre, de la pomme verte et une tranche de pamplemousse pour bien trancher, justement, lacidité du reste.

[18-OCT-2013] Hand Pump at Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fà in Rome. Pours brown to orange with a small head, aroma of malt, brett, lemon, leaves, vinegar, flavor is sour with lemon, green tea, bitterness, pretty fun to drink, medium bodied

[10/18/13] Hand-pump at Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fà in Rome. Hazy amber with a bit of off-white foam. Lovely barnyard aroma with oak, a bit of malt and some fruitiness. Sour oaky flavor with barnyard, some fruitiness, a bit of vinegar and a slightly astringent finish, somewhat puckering, with a bit of bitterness. Medium-bodied. Very nice.

Had on Zwanze Day! at the Avenue Pub, New Orleans,LA .. . . Pours a deep gold, lightly hazed .. . good foam .. . mild yeast, wood, wet wood, medium tartness, and bitter hay .. . a milder unblended but quite enjoyable .. . .  Rock, good old rock, nothing beats that!

Draught at Volos 25th Anniversary Party. Pours a deep orange-amber with no head. Aroma is awesome: Sour, tart and funky and sour, tart and funky. Flavour of sour fruit, vinegar, lemon, funky yeast, salt and dish soap, all in a great way. Average bodied. Certainly an interesting beer, not one of Cantillons best but still a really good one.

I generally dislike still alcoholic beverages. This is no exception, with a completely flat mouthfeel that lets the vinegary character of the lambic come through a bit too much. Another Cantillon I could take or leave.

2013-09-28. Hazy dark amber body, headless 3+ Aroma is pleasant, relatively mild, light funk and light musty character. 7+ Flavour is pleasantly sour, with notes of lemon and pretty mild funk throughout. Relatively bitter in the finish. Average bodied palate, low carbonation. Very nice sour, it is not super complex but has a depth of flavour to it that is quite pleasant. On tap at Volo 25th Anniversary Party

hazy brown red, glowing, thin small bubbled ring, no lasting head, still otherwise. Earth nose, hay and rhubarb, bit of grassy hop. Thin, light acetic , real dry and slick, earthy with considerable hay, light phenolics. Dry and sticky, earthy but the acetic sparkle keeps it playful.
On tap at Bar Volo 25th Anniversary. Complex sour, very drinkable. Light colour and somewhat sour aroma.

Tap at Holy Grale for Zwanze Day 2013. Clear amber to copper pour with a thin, bubbly head. Aroma of malt vinegar, peppery yeast, some citrus and grassy hops. Malty and grassy hop flavor with some vinegar character before a bitter hop finish.

Enjoyed at Zwanze Day 2013.

Pours reddish in color, flat. Nose is citrus, vinegar, lots of oak, hay. Flavor is lemon, vinegar, oak, and light funk. Body is light, flat, and medium-dry finish.

Overall, decent but I prefer Iris with a lot of age on it, and this is no exception.
this was a mess, not understanding the ratings, smelled ok but weird tastes of plastic, not a winner.

On draught for Zwanze Day 2013 at Avenue Pub! Pours a hazy reddish brown with little to no head or lacing. Aroma is lactic sourness, fruity sweetness, and a nice funky straw finish. Taste follows, lots of nice balance, sweet up front, malty middle, sour ending. Very nice, dry and refreshing finish.

Draft at ChurchKey for Zwanze Day. Slightly cloudy red/amber, little to no head. Beautiful earthy, horseblanket character mixed with bits of leather, tobacco, very light citrus, hints of pepper. This lovely subtle complexity continues through the flavor with the oak definitely coming through with touches of tannic acidity, great balance to the funk. Delightful.

An enormous thank you goes out to Matt for ensuring I was able to try this. 6 ounce sample into my Cantillon taster.

The beer is copper to auburn colored and still. The aroma brings a grandiose funky oak character, with notes of sourness, perhaps gooseberries. Musty vanilla and wet wood. Smells like a rainy day on the deck. Hey, it is a rainy day on the deck. Tart and funky, finishing dry. The feel and elegance of white wine. I really enjoy this.

14/IX/13 - Zwanzeday! - on tap @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas (Brussels) - BB: n/a (2013-863)Thanks to PriorL and Mathieu87 for sharing!
Clear dark orange to amber beer, no head. Aroma: bit sweet, caramelly, soapy, lots of sherry notes, bit spicy, orange peel, fruity. MF: soft to no carbon, light to medium body. Taste: very bitter start, sour notes, fruity, some chloride, metallic bitterness, zesty, Moroccan preserved lemons (salty). Aftertaste: very bitter, metallic, lemony, bit spicy, dry ending.

TAP at Moeder Lambic Fontainas on Zwanze Day.
APPEARANCE: light clouded amber beer, no foam.
NOSE: heavy, alcohol, lots of malts, wood.
TASTE: fruity, malts, wood, alcohol, little sugar, dry ,little hop.

Tasted @ Zwanze day 2013 - Appearance: Light brown colour with reddish tint. No head - Aroma: Sour and oak - Flavour: Barnyard, wet hay and stewed apple - Overall: Clean crisp and sour aftertaste. No carbonation.

Draft at Holy Grale in Louisville, Zwanze Day 2013. Pours a hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma of earthy hops, oak, dust, cheesecloth, a little bit of yogurt and lemon, and musty funk. Flavor of stale bread, oak, lemon, cheesy funk, dust, apple cider vinegar, and musty grains. Got a significant brine flavor as it warmed, but I wont hold that too much against it because we were outside in the sun all day. Light-bodied, with a dry, tart, funky, stale mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Pretty interesting. Drew mixed opinions from the group, but I had one of the more favorable ones. Really interesting.

Sampled cask @ Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas during Zwanze day 2013. Pours a very dark burned sugar amber lambic with only some lambic bubbles on the sides. Looks like lambic but darker than usual. Overall this is basically a 3 year old lambic without wheat & 50/50 dried & fresh hops instead of the usual recipe, taste-wise has nothing in common the regular Iris, big surprise. Nose is almost sweet with burned sugar, caramel, touch toffee and thick oily lambic mixed with those flavours. Taste like very old lambic, older than 3 years, has that herbal profile of very old lambic, hitter herbs, oily, touch burned sugar, reminds me a bit of LH12. Like it quite a bit more than Bruocsella or in general regular old lambic. Pretty oily, thicker base body than usual, flat. Very different from what I expected but pleasant surprise, dig it a bit more than the usual Iris. Great unblended lambic, would love to try a geuze made, using this. (Thx! for sharing people!)

Tap @ De Bierkoning, Zwanze Day. Brown-ish color. Aromas: quite sour, lots of wood. Flavor is full on sour, but still with a faint sweetness somewhere in the background. Alcohol noticeable. Body is on the thin side. Finishes very dry. Nice one.

14/09/2013 Ma che siete venuti a fà (tap). Ambrata con riflessi arancia, schiuma bianca leggera e poco abbondante. Al naso sentori vinosi, ciliegia e frutta rossa, malto, leggero acetico. In bocca è moderatamente acida, addomesticata rispetto alla versione base, ma più complessa, aspra, acetica, limone, note legnose sul finale, molto astringente. Corpo medio-leggero, carbonazione soft. Complessa e originale, in una parola: spettacolare!

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2015 On tap @ Stone. Opaque orange pour with no head. Smells...old. Mild vinegar, some oak, and caramel. A touch of cardboard, grass, musty, and lemon juice. Flavor is kind of meh too. Sweet malt, vinegar, cardboard, and grass. Lemon juice, light oak, and musty, earthy funk. (Sep. 14, 2013)

On tap @ Beachwood BBQ. Hazed, muddy burnt orange pour with minimal foam. Smells mostly like green apple peels and lemon juice. A light acetic quality, some musty, mushroomy funk, and old library books. Certainly sour, but slick, flat, and lackluster. A let down...again, even though I kind of already knew I didnt like it. (Sep. 19, 2015)

Floral, funky and slightly acetic aroma. Pours a reddish amber with no real head just some slight bubble formation around the edges of the glass. The taste is great; moderately sour but doesnt quite grab you in the back of the jaw like some of their more sour stuff but it rounds out with some nice earthy citrus bitterness. Light and smooth body.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Zwanze Day 2013. Amber-orange, clear, bubbly low head. Nose of lemon, some vinegar, yogurt, sour cream, light hops, horse blanket. Malty flavor, caramel, yogurt, very lemony and earthy, leather, grassy hops. Nice stuff, like an old lambic but a bit more malty, some hops.

Tap @ De Bierkoning, Zwanze Day, Amsterdam. Pours a hazy dark amber. Aroma is sour, candy, cherry, apple skin. Funk. Taste is sour with apple skin, dry, bile. Delicious. Smooth, decent carbonation. Turns a bit sticky, mouth-puckering. Goes to your gums. Delicious.

Sampled at Zwanze Day at WLV. Pours a very dark orange/brown in color with very head little. Some bubbles around the ring of the glass but no real head formation. Nose reminds me of grand cru brouscella. Flavor is a little yogurty, lemon rind, musty, and slightly acetic. Mouthfeel is light, lightly carbed, somewhat silky, and a moderate finish. Pretty good, I like it, but I think I prefer the regular iris.

Draft at LWW Zwanze Day event in Chicago. Pours reddish amber with minimal head. Sour / funky taste with similar nose ... Very tasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Zwanze Day 2013 at West Lakeview. Pours a deep amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity, lemon, yeasty, floral. Medium on the palate with very light carbonation. Almost flat. Flavor is sour, lemon, grapefruit, a little bready, with a light, sour grapefruit finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2014 On draft at Monks for Zwanze day with Simon and Barry. Pours very still brown with no head or lacing really, Notes of grape skin, funk, granny smith, oak, and barn. Lots of smooth oak but a little faint in aroma/flavor. Medium to fuller body with light carbonation. Prefer the regular Iris to this one but still nice. Tried again a couple months ago and it was hard to get down. Really flat and bland.

Zwanze Day! Iced tea pour, no head. Aroma is funky and briny, rotting wood, tart dark fruit and malt. Flavor is super oaky and acidic, light malt vinegar notes, lemon drupelets, sour cherry, basement. No carbonation but thats okay.

Aroma has moderate fruit notes with some raisin and prune notes. Faint barnyard character with a hint of cherry. Some acetic character along with a medium oak note. Light buttery character. 
Pours an almost still copper with some brown highlights. Darker than the regular Iris. 
Flavor is fairly dry with some dark fruit - cherry and prune as well as plum. Moderate acidity with a touch of an acetic character. Low citrus notes and moderate barnyard funk. I think the phenolics I attribute to fresh Iris are actually the hops. Low bitterness with some lingering dark cherry notes and light barnyard funk. Definitely more acetic. Moderate oak notes but lighter than I was expecting. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with no carbonation. Low acidic astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall an interesting interpretation of Iris. I think I enjoy it more than the Grand Cru Bruscella but less than the regular Iris. Lots more dark fruit and a bit more acetic acid.

Draft at bierkoning Amsterdam. Pours hazy reddish copper. Aroma is vinegar, funk, barnyard and red fruits. Taste is oak, acidic and woody. Quite sour. Light bitter. Very very good, better than the normal iris for sure. Very complex. Long sour finish. Medium body with soft carbonation.

On draft at Churchkey DC on Zwanze Day. Pours a hazy cider brown with a slight bubbly head that receded to nothing in nothing flat. Aroma of tart greeen apples. Delicate flavors of funk, tart apple, white pepper. Mellow low carbonation moouthfeel. Short tart finish. A classic.

Pouring at Stone Zwanze Day. Rating #6400. Flat, murky deep orange amber tea pour. Fine for unblended. Nose is a tad sticky, sweaty, something savory like worchestershire sauce. Taste is tangy, rich fruit leather, soft red grapefruit, mild thicker buttery biscuit. Superlative Iris palate is still there. But overall this is softer all around than normal Iris. Really nice spicy oak in the back. Leathery, near slick body. Long lactic finish with spicy red grapefruit flashes.Second pour: as it warms nose finally comes around as richer albeit still soft maple, pie, brown sugar rubbed red grapefruit. Very different from normal Iris with no hop character. Slick butteriness doesnt bother me since there is spicy grapefruit juice to cut through. Overall, I really enjoyed this especially the leathery palate that is the highlight of normal Iris. Still in love. Disclaimer: Im a rare Iris fanboy.

A glas at Cantillon. Thanks Jean. 

This is alot better than the regular Iris oak really beautifull in this one. Very complex and beautifully aged.
